The king of Tyre who supported King Solomon with timber for the building of the temple was
explanation: Hiram was the king of Tyre during the time of King Solomon.  In 1 Kings 5:1-12, it is mentioned that Hiram and Solomon entered into a friendly alliance. Hiram sent his servants to Solomon, and they, along with Solomon's workers, cut down cedar and cypress trees from the forests of Lebanon for the construction of the Temple in Jerusalem. Hiram's assistance was crucial for Solomon in obtaining high-quality timber for the temple's construction.

Which of the following people led the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem after the Jews returned from exile?
Two kings of Persia who passed decrees to bring about the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem were
explanation: The correct answer is B. Darius and Cyrus. These two Persian kings issued decrees that allowed for the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem. The decree of Cyrus is recorded in the book of Ezra 1:1-4, where Cyrus, the king of Persia, issues a proclamation allowing the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple. The decree of Darius is mentioned in the book of Ezra 6:1-12. In this passage, Darius confirms and strengthens the decree of Cyrus, ensuring that the temple reconstruction continues despite opposition.

text: The Jew who came from exile to Jerusalem to study the law of the Lord and teach others was
explanation: Ezra is known for his dedication to studying and teaching the Law of Moses. He led a group of Jewish exiles back to Jerusalem from Babylon during the Persian Empire period, and he played a crucial role in promoting the understanding and observance of the law among the returned exiles.

text: According to Luke's gospel, when the Devil had ended the temptation of Jesus, the Devil departed

options.A: and Jesus was baptized in the Jordan
options.B: to work out a better strategy
options.D: and Angels came to minister to Jesus because he had accomplished His mission

explanation:
In the Gospel of Luke, after the Devil had tempted Jesus in the wilderness, we find the account in Luke 4:13 (NIV):
"When the devil had finished all this tempting, he left him until an opportune time."
The statement implies that the Devil departed, it is commonly interpreted that the Devil left with a sense of defeat and embarrassment because Jesus successfully resisted all the temptations. The departure of the Devils means that Jesus overcame the temptations and remained faithful to God's will. The idea is that the Devil retreated temporarily, waiting for another opportunity to tempt Jesus.

explanation: The Bible records that Jesus stood in a boat belonging to Peter on the Sea of Galilee (Lake of Gennesaret) to teach the crowd.
